seg.seg: sufferings. [21d] This they heard, [and] manifold thereupon they divided [their] thinking: There is no deliverance from the sufferings in any permanent path. These so great sages have not made the sufferings disappear permanently. Here there is not
Dieses hörten sie, [und] vielfach spalteten sie darauf ihr Denken.
This they heard, [and] manifold then they divided their thinking.
Or isn't there any way here that makes sorrow disappear?

this path yet that makes the suffering disappear. [22d] [In order] to drive out from these this depression of the mind and the suffering, the Omniscient proclaimed the strophes in the assembly, to comfort their mind: To perma-
-nently cease and continually be capable of purity, to make disappear the cycle of birth and death [23d] and to recognize the countless births this path as the best

one was revealed by the one who knows the world, the noble. Just like the water having come into the Gaṅgā flows together flawlessly with the ocean, in this way [also] this eightfold path which has been proclaimed (flows) [24d]
together to reach immortality. This strophe as the second the God of Gods proclaimed there, to comfort these beings. This also he made them know: There is here [only] one way out of the Saṃsāra

(towards the permanent) deliverance (of the world) from the sufferings, [namely] the eightfold, noble, [25d] destroying all kleśas, making all births end, like cutting off desease, old-age, death and birth.

The miserable (beings have missed the path), even great sages. On a wrong path they are desiring deliverance, therefore they do not achieve [it]. [26d] But the eightfold path proclaimed by me [is] destroying the births. The seven
Die unglücklichen (Wesen haben den Weg verfehlt), auch große Weise. Auf falschem Wege suchen sie die Erlösung, deshalb erlangen sie [sie] nicht.
The unhappy (beings have missed [their] way), even great sages. On the wrong path they seek redemption, therefore they do not obtain [it].

(factors of enlightenment) ... it reaches. Like the waters from the rivers, when they descend directed towards the Gaṅgā, all become glorious, all go towards the sea, [27d] [just] so (towards the) Brahma(world)

[Just as] the waters from the rivers, if they descend towards the Ganges, all become glorious and all go towards the ocean, so to the Brahma world … all are turned towards the nirvāṇa and leave the house. (cf : ii, 50)

... all are turned towards the Nirvāṇa [and] go (from the house). On the body of the Buddha they see the jewel[signs] and characteristics (of excellence), [and] (on the body) fathom wide rays covered his golden skin

, [28d], which, together with odour, drove off all kleśas and defeated the four Māras. [His] own good, which he had done, of it the beings had heard. In what way, however, (for everyone he did good things, the)
sage of the Śākyas, the world’s doubt [about this] he intended to cut off, [and] he proclaimed this strophe to them: [29d] He who turned the good wheel of the law, thus far unheard, all beings
he loves, for everyone in [his] cycle of births, such a being like this, most excellent among gods and men, one shall at all times venerate as the one having passed across the sea of birth. [30d]
Durch das Drehen des Gesetzesrades erlöste er [scil. der Buddha] die Wesen.
By turning the wheel of the law, he [i.e. the Buddha] has redeemed the beings.

By the turning of the wheel of the law he freed the beings; he, the one always striving for [his] own [salvation and], equally, the salvation of the others, is to be venerated. [The turning] of the wheel of the law, which is called
... durch das Drehen des Gesetzesrades ...
... by turning the Wheel of the Law ...
"Gesetzesrad" [ist das], was darśanamārga [Weg der Erkenntnis] mit Namen genannt wird.
"Wheel of the Law" [this is], what is called darśanamārga [path of seeing] by name.

the Darśanamārga ["the path of vision”] by name. Within fifteen moments the five elements turn, – hence the name Dharmacakra [“wheel of the law”] – , [31d] above and below. The spokes that are below when the wheel turns, they turn upwards and
Up and down turn those spokes when the wheel turns: those which are down turn upwards, [and] from above again downwards. (cf : ii, 51)

Innerhalb von fünfzehn Augenblicken drehen sich die fünf Skandhas, - [daher] der Name Dharmacakra [Rad des Gesetzes] - oben [und] unten um. Die Speichen, welche, wenn das Rad sich dreht, [gerade] unten sind, die drehen sich nach oben um [und] von oben wiederum nach unten.

Within fifteen moments the five skandhas, - [hence] the name dharmacakra [wheel of the law] - turn around above [and] below. The spokes, which, when the wheel turns, are below, these turn upwards [and] from above downwards again.
